7.13.18  8:37 am   hey bill,

i have this problem where i don't know who i am. i really want to know what i want to do with my life and who i want to be, but i feel like it changes from one day to the next. i'm just about to graduate from college with a major in physics, and some days i love science and other days i'm sick of it and all i want to do is be creative and write songs. i keep switching between so many things and i can't make up my mind. i also struggle with my personality and what kind of person i want to be. i got married so young and i feel like i haven't been able to be myself and take on the world as an individual. i feel as if my personality is clouded by my husband and who he wants me to be, not who i really want to be. i guess i'm just stuck in this never ending cycle of wanting to try new things and be myself, and i don't know what thing i want to stick with or who myself is. i think it might be that i want to be someone that my husband an d family don't want me to be, but is it worth being myself and risking losing them? how do i even do that when i have no support? how do i try to be myself when i don't really know who that is? sorry if this is rambly. i have no one to talk to about this and you are full of so much wisdom.

thanks

7.12.18  8:12 pm   This is sort of a loaded question, but I'd love to hear your thoughts if you have the time.
Some of the most critically acclaimed and widely appreciated popular musicians (and even some composers) over the last century are said to have had little or no academic background or classical training in music, yet seem to possess incredible technical skill sets as well as an intuitive understanding of composition and harmony.
